What’s the average retirement age for NFL kickers?

Determining the exact average retirement age for NFL kickers is challenging due to variations in individual careers and the lack of comprehensive data. However, kickers generally enjoy longer careers compared to other positions in the NFL. The average career length for kickers and punters is approximately 4.87 years, which is notably higher than the league-wide average of 3.3 years.

In terms of age, the average NFL kicker is around 29 years old. Many kickers continue playing into their late 30s and even early 40s. For instance, as of 2024, Nick Folk and Matt Prater were both active at 40 years old.

Given these figures, it's reasonable to infer that the average retirement age for NFL kickers falls between 35 and 40 years old, allowing for individual differences in performance, health, and team needs.

Deep research

What’s the average retirement age for nfl kickers

NFL kickers tend to retire significantly later than most other players. While the average NFL player retires around age 27–28 due to the league’s physical toll, kickers often play well beyond 30. In fact, kickers have the longest careers on average of any position – roughly 4.8 seasons on average, compared to about 3.3 for all players (running backs average only ~2.5). Starting their careers in their early 20s, an “average” kicker might retire around age 30. However, it’s very common for successful NFL kickers to continue into their late 30s and even their 40s. A reliable, productive kicker can stick around for two decades in the league.

Range: On the low end, some kickers see their careers end in their 20s if they struggle or are replaced by younger competition. But at the high end, kickers are the ones who often push the boundaries of age in the NFL. Many of the oldest players in NFL history have been kickers. For example, George Blanda (who was also a quarterback) retired at 48 years old, the oldest ever. The next-oldest were all placekickers: Morten Andersen retired at 47, and John Carney and Adam Vinatieri each played until 46. It’s not unusual to see active kickers around 40; in 2025, two NFL kickers (Nick Folk and Matt Prater) were 40 years old. By contrast, players at high-contact positions (like running back or linebacker) rarely last past their early 30s.

Why kickers last longer: The main reason is that the physical demands of kicking are lower than other positions. Kickers aren’t subject to bone-crunching hits on every play. As one analysis notes, due to “less physical contact, positions like kickers (and quarterbacks) typically have longer careers” than collision-heavy positions. With fewer traumatic injuries and less wear-and-tear, a kicker’s body can hold up longer. Also, kicking is a specialized skill that relies more on technique, accuracy, and leg strength than on the raw speed or all-around athleticism that declines rapidly with age. Many kickers can maintain their leg power and refine their technique well into their late 30s or 40s.

Of course, kickers aren’t immune to aging. They do eventually experience diminishing leg strength or accuracy, which can prompt retirement. For instance, even legends like Vinatieri (the NFL’s all-time scoring leader) hung up the cleats once their performance started slipping in their mid-40s. Some kickers also decide to retire if they lose their job and opportunities dry up – effectively being “forced out” in their 20s or 30s despite not being physically broken. And on rare occasions, a kicker might retire early by choice (e.g. to pursue other careers or due to a persistent injury), though this is less common than at other positions.

In summary, NFL kickers enjoy unusual longevity. Many retire in their mid-to-late 30s – considerably later than the overall NFL average. It’s not uncommon for a top kicker to play 15+ years and approach age 40 before retiring. A handful of outliers have even kicked into their mid-40s. This longevity comes from the position’s lower physical strain and the fact that as long as a kicker stays accurate and effective, teams will keep him around. Meanwhile, the high-contact roles see careers end much sooner. As one sports writer put it, a dependable kicker can be in the NFL “for upwards of two decades,” whereas players taking the biggest pounding (running backs, linemen, etc.) tend to have the earliest retirements.

  • “The Brief Career of NFL Players” – longevity by position (RBC Wealth Mgmt. study)
  • Oldest NFL players records (BetMGM)
  • Position longevity explanation (NFL Exclusive)

Deep research provides components and factors to consider, rather than just a number. That level of detail and clarity makes it more informative and more directly responsive to someone wanting to understand retirement age trends in the NFL.

Expert-level task examples

I am a researcher interested in bringing mixed-gas sorption capabilities to my lab. Please discuss the differences between pure- and mixed-gas sorption for glassy polymers, how the dual-mode sorption model can be used to predict mixed-gas sorption behavior in glassy polymers (include equations where applicable), and what challenges there are in accurately predicting pure- and mixed-gas sorption using the dual-mode sorption model. Only include open-source information as of October 1, 2024.

Pure vs. mixed-gas sorption in glassy polymers: In a glassy polymer (below TgT_gTg​), a single gas typically exhibits a concave sorption isotherm: uptake rises sublinearly with pressure, unlike the linear Henry’s-law behavior above TgT_gTg​. This is attributed to “dual-mode” sorption: some penetrant dissolves in the dense polymer matrix (obeying Henry’s law) while additional penetrant saturates specific microvoid “sites” (a Langmuir-type adsorption in the polymer’s nonequilibrium free volume). By contrast, when two or more gases are present, they compete for those limited Langmuir sorption sites. As a result, each component’s sorbed concentration in a mixture is generally lower than it would be at the same partial pressure alone. In particular the less soluble (lower-affinity) gas tends to be more strongly suppressed, often causing the mixed-gas solubility selectivity (ratio of concentrations) to exceed the ideal value predicted from pure-gas isotherms. For example, in CO₂/CH₄ mixtures both components sorb less than in their pure-gas cases (especially CH₄), so the CO₂/CH₄ sorption selectivity is higher under mixture conditions. In extreme cases, mixed-gas effects can even reverse performance trends observed with single gases. (We note that unlike competitive sorption, synergistic sorption – where one gas increases the sorption of another via polymer swelling – is usually minor in rigid high-free-volume polymers under moderate pressures.)

Dual-mode sorption model and mixed-gas prediction: The dual-mode sorption (DMS) model quantitatively captures glassy polymer sorption by superposing a Henry’s-law term and a Langmuir term. For a single gas, the sorbed concentration CCC (e.g. in cm³(STP) gas per cm³ polymer) is written as:

C(p)=kD p  +  CH′ b p 1+b p  .C(p) = k_D\,p \;+\; \frac{C'_H\,b\,p}{\,1 + b\,p\,}\,. C(p)=kD​p+1+bpCH′​bp​.

Here kDk_DkD​ is the Henry’s law coefficient for dissolution, CH′C'_HCH′​ is the Langmuir capacity constant (proportional to the polymer’s unrelaxed free-volume or “hole” capacity), and bbb is the Langmuir affinity constant. This empirical formula yields the characteristic concave isotherm of glassy polymers and reduces to simple Henry’s law at the glass-transition (since CH′→0C'_H \to 0CH′​→0 as T→TgT \to T_gT→Tg​). The same three parameters (kD,CH′,bk_D, C'_H, bkD​,CH′​,b) are obtained by fitting pure-gas sorption data and are then used to predict mixture sorption. For a binary mixture of gases A and B (with partial pressures pA,pBp_A, p_BpA​,pB​), the DMS model assumes each gas obeys its own Henry’s term and that both compete for the same Langmuir sites. One convenient form is to write the total sorbed concentration as the sum of contributions from each gas:

Ctot=kD,ApA+kD,BpB  +   CH,A′ bA pA  +  CH,B′ bB pB  1+bApA+bBpB  ,C_{\text{tot}} = k_{D,A}p_A + k_{D,B}p_B \;+\; \frac{\,C'_{H,A}\,b_A\,p_A \;+\; C'_{H,B}\,b_B\,p_B\,}{\,1 + b_A p_A + b_B p_B\,}\,,Ctot​=kD,A​pA​+kD,B​pB​+1+bA​pA​+bB​pB​CH,A′​bA​pA​+CH,B′​bB​pB​​,

which implicitly means the concentration of component i in the mixture is Ci=kD,ipi+CH,i′bipi 1+∑jbjpj C_i = k_{D,i} p_i + \frac{C'_{H,i} b_i p_i}{\,1+\sum_j b_j p_j\,}Ci​=kD,i​pi​+1+∑j​bj​pj​CH,i′​bi​pi​​. This reduces to the single-gas formula when the other component’s pressure is zero. In practice, partial pressure in these equations is often replaced by fugacity for accuracy at high pressures, though using fugacities or pressures gives nearly the same results if applied consistently. The DMS mixed-gas model predicts the competitive sorption effect observed experimentally – namely, each gas’s uptake is depressed relative to its pure-gas sorption isotherm.

Challenges and limitations: Although the dual-mode model is widely successful in correlating sorption data, it has notable limitations in predicting sorption behavior. First, the DMS model is empirical – its fitted parameters are not universal constants but can vary with polymer formation history, physical aging, and temperature/pressure range. This means a parameter set obtained under one set of conditions may lack predictive power outside its calibration range. For instance, sorption isotherms measured only over a limited pressure range can be fit well by DMS, but extrapolating beyond that (especially approaching plasticization pressures) may be unreliable. Indeed, multiple distinct combinations of kDk_DkD​, CH′C'_HCH′​, bbb can sometimes fit the same pure-gas isotherm almost equally well – yet they yield markedly different mixed-gas predictions. This sensitivity undermines confidence in mixture forecasts, as one study showed that using different pure-gas fit sets led to only qualitative agreement with some mixed-CO₂/CH₄ data.

Furthermore, DMS inherently assumes a fixed population of Langmuir sites (microvoids) and ignores polymer relaxation or swelling induced by sorbate. In reality, penetrant-induced swelling (plasticization) can increase free volume and sorption capacity, especially for highly condensable gases at high activity – an effect the basic DMS model cannot capture. In binary sorption, this means any synergistic increase in sorption due to a second gas (or due to polymer dilation) is unaccounted for in the standard model. Conversely, the model also cannot describe sorption isotherm shapes that deviate from concave Langmuir-type behavior (e.g. sigmoidal isotherms caused by specific polymer-penetrant interactions or clustering). For example, glassy polymers absorbing polar molecules like alcohols can show sigmoidal sorption isotherms, which the simple dual-mode framework fails to represent. Finally, accurately measuring mixed-gas sorption itself is challenging, and discrepancies between idealized model assumptions (e.g. truly zero downstream pressure, no competitive diffusion limitations) and experimental realities can add to prediction error. Despite these challenges, the dual-mode sorption model – with appropriate care – remains a valuable first approximation for interpreting sorption in glassy polymers, and it highlights the key role of competitive site occupancy in mixed-gas environments. Researchers often turn to more elaborate models (e.g. non-equilibrium lattice fluid or thermodynamic theories) when the dual-mode model’s assumptions break down, but such models come at the cost of additional parameters or complexity. In summary, dual-mode sorption provides a useful baseline for pure- and mixed-gas sorption in glassy polymers, but one must be mindful of its empirical nature and the above limitations when predicting multicomponent sorption behavior in practice.

Sources: Dual-mode sorption model and mixed-gas extension; competitive sorption effects in mixtures; model equations and parameters; limitations of DMS model; parameter sensitivity and predictivity issues.

I am a linguist and was hired by a film production company. They want me to write some dialogues in English of 5 centuries later. Since in the movie the US is invaded by different nations with very different languages, English becomes a creole language, borrowing certain characteristics of each language. I want you to translate the sentences in (1) into this creole which has the features in (2).

(1) a. The cat is in the room.
b. The men loaded the truck with hay.
c. The dogs are barking.
d. What did you say that Mary buy?
e. Some rat ate the cheese.
f. I want a sweeter dish.
g. The most beautiful homes have been sold.
h. He could come earlier.

(2) a. English becomes a split ergative language based on 'verb type'. If the verb is intransitive, the Subject bears Nominative Case, and if the verb is transitive, the Subject bears Ergative Case and the Object bears Absolutive Case. Case markers are borrowed from Hindi.

b. The word order of English also changes. It is a verb final language: SOV

c. Articles (a/an/the), modal and auxiliary verbs (may, should, must, etc.) and prepositions (in, at, on, etc) are prefixes. If more then one of them occur together, they can be prefixed as a cluster to the first content word in the phrase: 'on a barn' --> 'onabarn'

d. In wh-questions, the wh-phrase is pronounced at the beginning of a sentence, in its base position and also at the beginning of each clause in between (I am ignoring other changes such as word order, ergativity etc.):

"Which cake did you say which cake Mary cooked which cake?"

e. Expletive 'there' can be used with transitive verbs as long as the Subject is indefinite, as in Icelandic.

f. Comparative forms of adjectives are derived via partial reduplication: the first consonant + the first vowel of the adjective/adverb is copied and added to the adjective/adverb as a prefix. If the adjective starts with a vowel, 'm' is added in between the vowel and the adjective/adverb. If the adjective/adverb starts with a consonant cluster , the last consonant in the cluster + the first vowel is copied, e.g. 'more beautiful' --> 'bebeautiful' (for such reduplication, you cal look into emphatic reduplication of adjectives in Turkish)

g. Superlative forms of adjectives are derived via doubling: the adjective/adverb is reduplicated, e.g. 'the shortest' --> 'short short'

While applying the processes in (2), keep in mind that from Hindi this creole borrows only case markers, nothing else. For each process listed in (2), do research on each and provide at least one academic resource. If a language is specified (such as Hindi, Icelandic), do research on the relevant process in that specific language. For each sentence in (1), explain your thought and translation process.

Please prepare the doc in txt format. Use online sources (e.g., journal papers, dissertations, books, book chapters, conference papers, abstracts, etc.) available before October, 5 2024. Provide in-text citations to academic sources as appropriate and provide a reference list WITH HYPERLINKS TO EACH SOURCE CITED at the very end.

Split Ergativity and Hindi Case Markers (2a): The future creole uses an ergative–absolutive alignment: transitive clauses mark the subject with an ergative case and the object with absolutive case, whereas intransitive subjects carry nominative (absolutive) case. This mirrors Hindi’s split-ergative system (by aspect), where -ne marks transitive subjects (ergative) and unmarked nouns serve as absolutive/nominative. Hindi also has a particle -ko for specific objects (accusative/dative). We borrow these case markers (and only these from Hindi). For example, Hindi “Ram=ne kitab kharida” (“Ram-ERG bought a book”) marks “Ram” with -ne. In our creole, a transitive subject likewise takes -ne, and (optionally) a definite object takes -ko (if specific), while intransitive subjects remain unmarked (absolutive). This split by verb type (transitive vs intransitive) is a hallmark of ergative alignment. We see similar patterns in many ergative languages (e.g. Basque, Hindi, etc.), where the sole argument of an intransitive behaves like the object of a transitive.

Verb-Final Word Order (2b): The creole’s syntax has shifted to SOV (Subject–Object–Verb) order, meaning the verb comes last in a clause. SOV is cross-linguistically very common (the single most frequent basic order) and is found in languages that likely influence this creole (e.g. Hindi, Turkish, Japanese are SOV). Adopting SOV, our examples will place the verb or verb cluster at the end of the sentence. This change aligns English with a typologically prevalent pattern.

Cliticized Articles, Auxiliaries/Modals, and Prepositions (2c): Functional words like definite/indefinite articles (“the, a”), auxiliary or modal verbs (“is, have, may, could”), and prepositions (“in, on, with”, etc.) become proclitic prefixes attached to the following content word. In other words, these normally separate words are phonologically bound to the content word they modify. Linguistically, these elements behave like clitics – prosodically weak function words (articles, prepositions, auxiliaries, etc.) that must attach to a host. If multiple such clitics occur in a row, they form a cluster prefixed to the first content word of that phrase. This is analogous to how, for example, Romance languages contract prepositions and articles (Italian di + il → del), or how clitic pronouns and auxiliaries cluster in Balkan languages. In our creole, “on a barn” would be realized as “onabarn” (with on+a prefixed to “barn”), as given. This kind of clustering has precedent in natural languages: many languages allow sequences of clitics (e.g. prepositions, articles) to attach to a content word as a unit. We will apply this rule in the translations, eliminating spaces between these function words and the nouns/verbs they accompany.

Wh-Phrase Copying in Questions (2d): Wh- questions in the creole exhibit a striking wh-copying strategy. The wh-phrase appears not only in sentence-initial position, but is also pronounced at the start of each subordinate clause and in its original base position. This resembles phenomena observed in some languages and learner speech where long-distance wh-movement leaves overt copies. For instance, certain German dialects and Afrikaans use wh-copying: cf. an Afrikaans example “Watter meisie sê hy watter meisie kom vanaand kuier?” (“Which girl did he say which girl is coming to visit tonight?”). Here “watter meisie” (“which girl”) is repeated in the matrix clause, embedded clause, and the gap position. Our creole does the same: “Which cake did you say which cake Mary cooked which cake?” has the wh-phrase “which cake” at the front, at the start of the embedded clause, and again where Mary’s object would be. This is reminiscent of natural wh-copy constructions documented by linguists. It diverges from standard English (which only fronts one wh-word), but is a consistent rule in the creole’s syntax for clarity.

Transitive Expletive ‘there’ (2e): The expletive “there” is used in the creole with transitive verbs when the logical subject is indefinite, akin to Icelandic transitive expletive constructions. In Icelandic, for example, one can say “Það hafa margir jólasveinar borðað búðinginn” which literally means “There have many elves eaten the pudding,” where “many elves” is an indefinite subject after the verb. Only Icelandic (among the Germanic languages) permits such constructions freely. Our creole similarly allows “there” to introduce a clause even if a transitive verb follows, provided the subject is nonspecific (“indefinite”). This is an extension of English existential there, now applicable to active sentences. We will see this in the translation of sentence (e), where an indefinite subject (“some rat”) is introduced by “there”. This usage echoes Icelandic’s syntax and relaxes standard English’s constraint (which normally forbids “there” with an active transitive).

Comparative Adjective Reduplication (2f): The creole forms comparatives by partial reduplication of the adjective or adverb. Specifically, the first consonant + vowel of the base adjective is copied as a prefix to the adjective. (If the adjective begins with a vowel, we insert an m between the repeated vowel and the base; if it begins with a consonant cluster, we use the last consonant of the cluster plus the first vowel.) This process is modeled on the emphatic reduplication in Turkish, where an adjective like “siyah” (“black”) becomes “simsiyah” (“deep black”, very black) – here si- (s+i) is copied and an epenthetic m is inserted, yielding “sim-”. Another example: “güzel” (“pretty”) → “güpgüzel” (“very pretty”), where gü (g+ü) is doubled with an inserted p. These are not comparatives in Turkish but intensive forms; our creole repurposes a similar mechanism for “more X” comparisons. For instance, “sweeter” (more sweet) might be rendered as “wesweet”, taking “sweet” (which starts with consonant cluster sw-) and prefixing we- (from w + e). This kind of reduplication-based grading is inspired by patterns in Turkish and other languages that create intensified or comparative meanings via reduplication. It departs from the English “-er” suffix or separate “more”, instead using a prefixed reduplicant to convey “more”. We will apply this to sentence (f).

Superlative by Doubling (2g): The creole expresses superlative “most X” or highest degree by full reduplication (doubling) of the adjective/adverb. Essentially, the adjective is stated twice in a row to signify the “-est” or “most” meaning. Reduplication for intensification or superlative effect is widely attested cross-linguistically. For example, in Fa d’Ambô Creole Portuguese, “féyu” (“ugly”) doubled as “fé féyu” means “very ugly” (literally “ugly ugly”). In some languages, this strategy equates to a superlative or an intensifier meaning “extremely X”. Our creole adopts doubling to mean “the X-est”. Thus “the most beautiful” would be rendered as “beautiful beautiful”, and “fastest” as “fast fast”, etc. We will see this in sentence (g). (Notably, this is analogous to how, say, Mandarin Chinese can repeat adjectives for emphasis, or how some English speakers might say “It’s hot, hot!” to mean “super hot”.) The definite article may still be used if needed (and prefixed to the doubled adjective phrase), but no separate “most” word appears – double saying the adjective communicates it is the maximal degree.

Now, let us apply these features to each sentence in (1), explaining each transformation step:

(1a) “The cat is in the room.” – This is an intransitive predication (location of “the cat”), so the subject “the cat” will be in the nominative (absolutive) case (no ergative marking). We convert word order to SOV, so the verb “is” (copula) should come at the end. Next, we prefix the article “the” onto “cat”: “thecat”. The locative phrase “in the room” becomes a single unit: we prefix the preposition and article onto “room”. “in the room” → “intheroom” (in+the+room). The copula “is” here functions as the main verb (a stative verb), so we leave it at the end (we do not treat it as a detachable auxiliary since it’s the copular verb). Putting it all together: “Thecat intheroom is.” This translated sentence places the verb last (SOV) and shows the merged preposition+article prefix. (We considered attaching “is” as a prefix — “thecat isintheroom” — but since “is” is the main verb, we keep it in final position to clearly illustrate verb-final order.)

Transl. (1a): “Thecat intheroom is.” > (Meaning: “The cat is in the room.”)

Process check: “The cat” → thecat (article prefix; no case marker because intransitive). “in the room” → intheroom (preposition+article clitic cluster). SOV order ⇒ “thecat intheroom is.” This aligns with an SOV structure seen in Hindi, Japanese, etc. and uses Hindi’s nominative (no marking) for the intransitive subject.

(1b) “The men loaded the truck with hay.” – Transitive clause (agent “the men”, object “the truck”). The verb “loaded” will go to sentence-final position. The subject “the men” is ergative-marked (since “load” is transitive). In Hindi, the ergative marker is -ne, so we suffix -ne: “themen-ne”. (“the men” also gets the article “the” prefixed: the+men). The object “the truck” is definite; in Hindi such a direct object would often take -ko. We attach -ko to mark the absolutive object (showing influence of Hindi’s differential object marking). Also prefix “the” to “truck”: “thetruck-ko”. The instrument phrase “with hay” becomes a prefix cluster: “withhay” (with+hay). Now assemble in SOV order: Subject (erg) – Object – Oblique – Verb. Thus: “Themen-ne thetruck-ko withhay loaded.” This means literally “The men-ERG the-truck-ACC with-hay loaded.” All features are visible: ergative -ne on the subject, cliticized “the”, and verb-final order.

Transl. (1b): “Themen-ne thetruck-ko withhay loaded.” > (Meaning: “The men loaded the truck with hay.”)

Process check: “The men” → themen-ne (article fused, ergative -ne added). “the truck” → thetruck-ko (article fused, -ko on definite object). “with hay” → withhay (preposition fused as prefix). Verb “loaded” at end. Ergativity borrowed from Hindi is reflected by -ne on the agent, and the clustering of “with+hay” is consistent with the creole’s agglutinative trend.

(1c) “The dogs are barking.” – This sentence describes an ongoing action by “the dogs” (plural subject). “Bark” is intransitive (no object), so “the dogs” will be nominative/absolutive (no -ne). We prefix the article: “thedogs”. The verb form “are barking” consists of auxiliary “are” + present participle “barking.” In our creole, auxiliaries attach as prefixes to the main verb. So “are” will prefix to “barking”, forming “arebarking” as a single verb complex. We then place this at the end (SOV order – though there is no object, the verb still comes last after the subject). The final sentence becomes: “Thedogs arebarking.” This translates literally to “The-dogs are-barking,” where are- is a clitic indicating present tense plural auxiliary. Such cliticization of auxiliaries is parallel to clitic forms in other languages (cf. Slavic clitic auxiliaries).

Transl. (1c): “Thedogs arebarking.” > (Meaning: “The dogs are barking.”)

Process check: “The dogs” → thedogs (article fused, no case suffix since intransitive). “are barking” → arebarking (auxiliary are prefixed to verb “barking”). Verb-final structure achieved trivially as “arebarking” follows the subject. The cluster arebarking shows how an auxiliary attaches to a content verb, a feature of our creole.

(1d) “What did you say that Mary buy?” – This corresponds to a wh-question with an embedded clause (“…that Mary buy”). The English sentence is ungrammatical as given (perhaps intended: “What did you say that Mary bought?”). In our creole, we’ll implement the wh-copying rule (2d). The wh-phrase here is “what”. We place “what” at the start of the matrix question, and also at the start of the embedded clause and in the object position of “buy” within the embedded clause. The basic word order will be SOV and ergative marking where appropriate. Let’s break it down:

  • Main clause: “you said that Mary buy what.” In SOV, “you” (subject) – “that Mary buy what” (object clause) – “said” (verb). “You” is a transitive subject (yousaidsomething), so it takes-ne:“you-ne”(assuming “you” is indefinite here just as a pronoun, we apply ergative). The verb “said” goes to the end.
  • Embedded clause: “Mary buy what.” “Mary” is the subject of “buy”, which is transitive. So “Mary” gets ergative-ne:Mary-ne. The object of “buy” is “what” – indefinite, we can mark it absolutive (no marker or perhaps-ko, but “what” as an interrogative pronoun we likely leave unmarked). According to rule (2d), we put “what” at thebeginningof this embedded clause as well, effectively doubling it in that clause. So it appears before “Mary-ne”andafter (in object position).
  • Now add the wh at the very front of the whole sentence too. So the sequence begins with “What” (the wh-word copied to matrix front), then presumably the main clause subject etc.

Assembling it: “What you-ne [what Mary-ne what buy] said?”. We also prefix any relevant function words: no articles here, but “did” (past auxiliary) in English question is not needed in our creole (tense can be handled by context or a clitic on “said” if needed). We might simply use the past form of “say” or a tense prefix. For simplicity, we can omit “did” entirely (since many languages don’t use a dummy auxiliary for questions). The result with wh-copying is: “What you-ne what Mary-ne what buy said?”. This directly exemplifies the structure: the wh-word “what” is present at the start of the question, at the start of the embedded clause (“…what Mary …”), and in the object position of “buy”. Such repetition is similar to documented wh-copy constructions.

To make it clearer, we can also prefix complementizer “that” to the embedded clause if needed: e.g., “that” could be a prefix on “Mary” (“thatMary-ne”), but the question already has multiple wh, so I will leave “that” implicit or treat it as optional (some languages drop “that” in speech). If we include it, it might appear as a prefix “thatMary-ne”. However, to keep focus on wh, I’ll omit an explicit “that”.

Transl. (1d): “What you-ne what Mary-ne what buy said?” > (Meaning: “What did you say that Mary bought?”)

Process check: We fronted “what” in the main clause and repeated “what” in the embedded clause’s Spec position and object position. “you” (transitive subject of “say”) got ergative -ne; “Mary” (transitive subject of “buy”) got -ne. SOV order: “you-ne … said” with the subordinate clause as the object. The structure is non-standard for English but follows our creole’s wh-copy rule and ergative marking. (This construction emphasizes the questioned object through repetition, a trait observed in languages with wh-copying.)

(1e) “Some rat ate the cheese.” – This is a transitive event with an indefinite subject “some rat”. According to rule (2e), we can use an expletive “there” because the subject is indefinite. In the creole, we begin the sentence with “There” (expletive pronoun). The real subject “some rat” will follow. We treat “some rat” as the logical subject of a transitive verb “ate”, so we give it the ergative marker -ne: “some rat-ne”. (“Some” is a determiner, not an article, so we do not prefix it – we leave “some” separate as in English.) Next, the object “the cheese” is definite, so we prefix the article and optionally mark it with -ko. “the cheese” → “thecheese-ko”. The verb “ate” goes at the end (SOV). Thus we get: “There some rat-ne thecheese-ko ate.”. This construction is modeled on Icelandic transitive expletives, where an expletive leads and the indefinite subject appears post-verbally or lower in the clause. In our creole’s SOV structure, “some rat-ne” still comes before the object and verb (we might imagine that in a more Icelandic-like structure it could follow the verb, but to keep consistent SOV ordering, we place it before the object here). The presence of “there” signals that the subject is non-specific, similar to English existential “There is a rat that ate the cheese,” except we’re not using a subordinate clause.

This sentence shows that the creole allows an expletive with a verb like “ate” (transitive), which standard English disallows. It’s grammatically fine here because “some rat” is indefinite. The ergative marking -ne on “rat” still indicates it’s the agent of eating, despite “there” occupying the initial slot.

Transl. (1e): “There somerat-ne thecheese-ko ate.” > (Meaning: “There [was] some rat ate the cheese.” i.e. “Some rat ate the cheese.”)

Process check: “some rat” → some rat-ne (ergative marked, subject is indefinite). “the cheese” → thecheese-ko (article fused, object marked -ko for specificity). Introduced “There” at start as expletive. Verb “ate” final. This mirrors Icelandic usage where an expletive allows an indefinite subject with a transitive verb. (Note: The structure without “there” would simply be “Somerat-ne thecheese-ko ate.”, which is also grammatical in the creole. The expletive adds an emphasis that such a rat existed, akin to saying “There was a rat that ate the cheese.”)

(1f) “I want a sweeter dish.” – This is a transitive construction (“I want [something]”). Subject “I” is ergative-marked (-ne) because “want” is transitive. So “I-ne” (“I” + ergative). The object is “a sweeter dish”. We handle the adjective “sweeter” with the comparative reduplication rule. The base adjective is “sweet”. It starts with the consonant cluster sw. According to our rule, we take the last consonant of that cluster (w) plus the first vowel (ee → “e”) and prefix that. Thus sweet → we-sweet. (This forms something like “wesweet”, meaning “more sweet” or “sweeter”). We then need to prefix the article “a” onto the first content word of the object phrase. The phrase “a sweeter dish” in SOV order will still be “[a sweeter dish]” as a noun phrase object. The first content word of this NP is the adjective “wesweet”. So we attach “a” to “wesweet”: “awesweet”. Now “dish” follows. So the object NP becomes “awesweet dish”. (No additional case marker on “dish” here, since in ergative alignment the object is absolutive; we might omit a -ko because it’s an indefinite nonspecific object.) Finally, the verb “want” goes at the end. “want” is a main verb here, but note that in English “want” doesn’t need an auxiliary. We have no extra articles or auxiliaries in front of it to prefix; we simply place “want” at the end. Thus the whole sentence: “I-ne awesweet dish want.”. This reads as “I-ERG a+we-sweet dish want.”

Let’s interpret “awesweet”: we formed “we-sweet” to mark the comparative (like “more sweet”), and we prefixed “a”. The reduplicative prefix “we-” is analogous to the Turkish-style intensification prefix (e.g. büyük “big” → bebüyük for “bigger” in our scheme, hypothetically). This makes “wesweet” mean “more sweet” (sweeter). We had to insert an epenthetic consonant for cluster sw, which the rule provided (taking “w” from the cluster). The result “awesweet” is somewhat complex morphologically, but it demonstrates the rule.

Transl. (1f): “I-ne awesweet dish want.” > (Meaning: “I want a sweeter dish.”)

Process check: “I” → I-ne (ergative marked first person). “a sweeter dish” → a + [we+sweet] dish = awesweet dish. Verb “want” at end. We see partial reduplication on “sweet” (sweet → wesweet) to convey “comparative”. The article is prefixed (a + wesweet). The ergative marking on “I” shows the transitive subject. In essence, this could be glossed as “I (ERG) a-more-sweet dish want.”

(1g) “The most beautiful homes have been sold.” – This sentence features a superlative (“the most beautiful”) and a passive/perfect construction (“have been sold”). Let’s handle the subject phrase first: “the most beautiful homes.” Using rule (2g), superlative by doubling, “the most beautiful” becomes “the beautiful beautiful”. We drop the separate word “most” and instead repeat “beautiful”. We also prefix “the” as required. Now, we must be careful how to prefix “the” here: The phrase “beautiful beautiful homes” – the first content word is the first “beautiful”. So we attach “the” to beautiful: “thebeautiful”, then a space, then the second “beautiful”. Thus the subject phrase is “thebeautiful beautiful homes”. (This corresponds to “the very beautiful homes” meaning “the most beautiful homes.”)

Next, the verb phrase “have been sold.” In our creole, auxiliaries cluster as prefixes onto the main verb. “Have been sold” consists of two auxiliaries (“have” for perfect, “been” for passive) plus the main verb “sold.” We cluster “havebeen” as a prefix onto “sold”: “havebeensold”. This entire cluster will function as the verb. We place it at the end (verb-final). Now, concerning case: “homes” is the subject of a passive sentence. In English it’s patient, not agent. In an ergative system, intransitive or passive subjects would normally be absolutive (unmarked). Since “sell” is originally transitive, “homes” are underlying objects (absolutive) that got promoted to subject. We will not use an ergative marker on “homes” because they are not the agent of a transitive action here (there is no explicit agent). So “homes” stays unmarked (nominative/absolutive). Additionally, because “homes” is plural and definite, Hindi might mark it with -ko if it were a direct object – but here it’s syntactically a subject. We’ll leave it unmarked to represent absolutive case.

So the assembled sentence: “Thebeautiful beautiful homes havebeensold.”. This reads as “The beautiful (reduplicated) homes have-been-sold.” The double “beautiful” encodes the superlative (essentially “most beautiful”). The cluster havebeensold shows auxiliaries prefixed to the verb. Notably, “havebeensold” is at the end, fulfilling SOV order (the whole verb complex is final).

Transl. (1g): “Thebeautiful beautiful homes havebeensold.” > (Meaning: “The most beautiful homes have been sold.”)

Process check: “the most beautiful homes” → thebeautiful beautiful homes (definite article prefixed to first “beautiful”; adjective “beautiful” doubled for superlative). No ergative on “homes” because the verb “sell” here is passive (no explicit agent). Verb “have been sold” → havebeensold (clustered auxiliaries as prefix on “sold”). This cluster is placed at sentence end. The outcome showcases both the reduplicative superlative (as in many languages where doubling marks intensity) and the auxiliary-cliticization. It’s equivalent to saying “The extremely beautiful homes sold (have been).”

(1h) “He could come earlier.” – This involves a modal (“could”) and a comparative adverb (“earlier” = “more early”). The subject “He” is performing an intransitive action “come”, so “he” will be nominative (no -ne). We prefix nothing to “He” (no article, it’s a pronoun). Next, “could” is a modal auxiliary, which in our creole will attach to the main verb “come”. So we plan to form “couldcome” as a single cluster. Now, “earlier” (comparative of “early”) should be formed via partial reduplication (2f). Base “early” starts with a vowel e. Rule: if an adjective/adverb begins with a vowel, we copy the vowel and insert “m” in between. So “early” → “e” + “m” + “early” = “emearly”. This “emearly” means “more early” (earlier). Now we have to place “emearly” in the sentence. In an SOV language, adverbs of time often appear before the verb (e.g., “He earlier come” essentially). We will put “emearly” before the verb cluster. Finally, we attach the modal “could” to “come” as “couldcome”, and put that at the end. The assembled order: “He emearly couldcome.”. This literally reads “He more-early could-come.” It means “He could come earlier.”

Let’s double-check clitics: “could” as a modal prefix sticks to “come”. No article or preposition to prefix in this sentence. Case: “He” is not marked (intransitive subject). So that’s done. One might ask: could we alternatively have attached “could” to “emearly” instead (since “earlier” is also a content word)? We treat “earlier” as an adjunct; the modal scopes over the verb “come”, so we attach it to the verb. The phrase “come earlier” as a whole has “come” as the main verb, which is where a modal clitic naturally attaches (similar to how in French, e.g., “il pourrait venir tôt” – one could imagine “pourrait” attaching to “venir” in a synthetic language). So couldcome is our verb complex. The word “emearly” comes before it as an adverb. The final word order “He [adv] [V]” is acceptable in SOV (many SOV languages put temporal adverbs before the verb).

Transl. (1h): “He emearly couldcome.” > (Meaning: “He could come earlier.”)

Process check: “He” → He (no case suffix, intransitive subject). “earlier” → emearly (partial reduplication: e + m + early; the e from “early” is copied, m inserted). Modal “could” + verb “come” → couldcome (cluster). We place “emearly” before the verb cluster to keep verb-final order. The comparative “emearly” shows the vowel reduplication rule (vowel-initial “early” gets prefixed with “e(m)-”) and effectively conveys “more early”. The final structure can be glossed as “He more-early could-come.”

In each of the above translations, we observe the interplay of the creole’s new features: ergative case marking from Hindi (-ne on transitive subjects, -ko on specific objects), SOV word order, and prefixation of function words (articles, prepositions, modals, auxiliaries) as clitics. The wh-question exemplifies the unusual wh-copying strategy found in some languages, and the expletive usage shows an Icelandic-like tolerance for “there” with active verbs. The reduplication processes for comparatives and superlatives are inspired by patterns in Turkish and other languages, where reduplication intensifies meaning. Overall, these translations illustrate a plausible English-based creole, 500 years in the future, enriched by typological features from Hindi, Turkish, Icelandic, etc., as specified in (2). Each change is grounded in real-world linguistic phenomena, as supported by the references below.

How many gene therapies have gained regulatory approval in the United States for the treatment of hemophilia as of October 15th 2024. Include the name of the developer company, as well as the respective year of approval. Provide a comprehensive summary of the viral vector technology employed in each of these approved therapies, highlighting key features.

As of October 15, 2024, three gene therapy products have been approved in the U.S. for treating hemophilia (two for hemophilia B and one for hemophilia A). These are:

  • Hemgenix (etranacogene dezaparvovec-drlb) – Developer: CSL Behring (in partnership with uniQure); FDA Approval: 2022. This was the first gene therapy for hemophilia B. Hemgenix is an in vivo AAV (adeno-associated virus) vector-based therapy delivering a functional Factor IX (FIX) gene. It uses an AAV serotype-5 capsid engineered to target hepatocytes (liver cells), where FIX is normally produced. The delivered gene is a codon-optimized “Padua” variant of human FIX, a high-activity mutant (R338L) that produces 5–8× higher FIX clotting activity than the wild-type protein. A liver-specific promoter drives FIX expression in transduced cells. A one-time IV infusion of this AAV5-Padua FIX construct can achieve sustained elevation of FIX levels and reduce bleeding episodes, obviating the need for regular prophylactic factor infusions.
  • Roctavian (valoctocogene roxaparvovec) – Developer: BioMarin Pharmaceutical; FDA Approval: 2023. This is the first gene therapy for hemophilia A. Roctavian also uses an AAV5 viral vector, which carries a human Factor VIII (FVIII) gene insert. Because the FVIII gene is large, Roctavian’s transgene is a B-domain–deleted FVIII (a shortened version of the gene with the non-essential B domain removed) so that it fits within the AAV’s packaging capacity. The AAV5 vector is administered as a one-time IV infusion and transduces liver cells, leading to endogenous production of Factor VIII in hepatocytes. This raises the patient’s FVIII levels and reduces bleeding risk long-term. (Notably, patients are screened to ensure they have no pre-existing neutralizing antibodies against AAV5, since anti-capsid immunity would block the gene delivery.)
  • Beqvez (fidanacogene elaparvovec-dzkt) – Developer: Pfizer; FDA Approval: 2024. This is the second gene therapy for hemophilia B (approved in April 2024). Beqvez employs a modified AAV vector with a serotype rh74 capsid (AAVrh74 variant) to deliver a FIX gene to the liver. Like Hemgenix, it encodes a hyperactive FIX Padua variant (R338L) to maximize clotting activity. The AAVrh74 capsid was chosen for its strong tropism for hepatocytes (the natural site of FIX synthesis) and relatively low prevalence of pre-existing immunity in humans. A single infusion of this AAVrh74-Padua FIX therapy enables the patient’s own liver to produce functional FIX, dramatically reducing or eliminating bleeding events and the need for regular FIX prophylaxis. (Patients must test negative for antibodies against the AAVrh74 capsid before receiving Beqvez, similar to the antibody screening required for Hemgenix/Roctavian.)

Sources: FDA approvals and company announcements for Hemgenix (2022), Roctavian (2023), and Beqvez (2024); and published summaries of each therapy’s AAV vector design and features. Each therapy uses a non-replicating AAV vector to deliver a one-time, liver-directed gene transfer, with serotype-specific capsids (AAV5 or AAVrh74) and optimized transgene cassettes (Padua FIX or B-domain–deleted FVIII) to achieve long-term clotting factor production in hemophilia patients.

Limitations

Deep research unlocks significant new capabilities, but it’s still early and has limitations. It can sometimes hallucinate facts in responses or make incorrect inferences, though at a notably lower rate than existing ChatGPT models, according to internal evaluations. It may struggle with distinguishing authoritative information from rumors, and currently shows weakness in confidence calibration, often failing to convey uncertainty accurately. At launch, there may be minor formatting errors in reports and citations, and tasks may take longer to kick off. We expect all these issues to quickly improve with more usage and time.

Access

Deep research in ChatGPT is currently very compute intensive. The longer it takes to research a query, the more inference compute is required. We are starting with a version optimized for Pro users today, with up to 100 queries per month. Plus and Team users will get access next, followed by Enterprise. We are still working on bringing access to users in the United Kingdom, Switzerland, and the European Economic Area. 

All paid users will soon get significantly higher rate limits when we release a faster, more cost-effective version of deep research powered by a smaller model that still provides high quality results. 

In the coming weeks and months, we’ll be working on the technical infrastructure, closely monitoring the current release, and conducting even more rigorous testing. This aligns with our principle of iterative deployment. If all safety checks continue to meet our release standards, we anticipate releasing deep research to Plus users in about a month.

What's next

Deep research is available today on ChatGPT web, and will be rolled out to mobile and desktop apps within the month. Currently, deep research can access the open web and any uploaded files. In the future, you’ll be able to connect to more specialized data sources—expanding its access to subscription-based or internal resources—to make its output even more robust and personalized.

Looking further ahead, we envision agentic experiences coming together in ChatGPT for asynchronous, real-world research and execution. The combination of deep research, which can perform asynchronous online investigation, and Operator, which can take real-world action, will enable ChatGPT to carry out increasingly sophisticated tasks for you.

Update on February 5, 2025: Deep research is now available to Pro users in the United Kingdom, Switzerland, and the European Economic Area.

Update on February 3, 2025: We conducted rigorous safety testing, preparedness evaluations, and governance reviews on the early version of o3 that powers deep research, identifying it as Medium⁠(opens in a new window) risk. We also ran additional safety testing to better understand incremental risks associated with deep research's ability to browse the web, and we have added new mitigations. We will continue to thoroughly test and closely monitor the current limited release. We will share our safety insights and safeguards for deep research in a system card when we widen access to Plus users.
